query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of providing supplementary food versus cover for farmland birds during winter?
relevant_summary: Evidence on supplementary food reports increases in farmland bird abundance, breeding population size, density, body mass, nestling growth and fledging rates, and increased overwinter survival in a declining house sparrow population, with use by target species such as tree sparrow, yellowhammer and corn bunting when food is provided [648]. Other studies found no clear effects on breeding abundance, turtle dove reproductive success, territory metrics, or overwinter survival of three stable house sparrow populations, with one study reporting lower fledging rates with food in one year and variable use by species, season and proximity to other food sources [648]. Evidence on sown wild bird seed/cover mixtures reports higher bird abundance, density, species diversity and richness than other farmland habitats, and frequent preference and use by birds, with some studies reporting mixed or negative effects; mixtures including kale or kale mixes attracted the most species or highest abundance in several studies [594]. Overwinter stubbles are associated with higher winter densities of farmland birds and positive associations for seed-eating birds, grey partridge productivity, and cirl bunting population size and territory density (often alongside other measures), with effects varying by species, stubble height and management, and some studies finding inconsistent or no effects or no preference over cover crops [203, 695].

query: What actions can be taken on farmland to support invertebrate populations like bees and beetles?
relevant_summary: Evidence-based farmland actions that support invertebrates include: creating beetle banks, which were associated with higher micro-moth richness and abundance than conventionally managed field margins, similar macro-moth abundance, and lower butterfly richness/abundance than hedgerows, with caterpillar abundance similar to margins and fields [3927]; planting new hedges, which increased beetle and spider abundance and diversity compared to crop fields or field margins, with reviews noting more ground beetles in newly established hedges and arthropod diversity varying by hedge plant species [538]; planting hedgerows, which in multiple replicated studies increased bee species richness (and sometimes syrphid fly species), raised native bee visitation rates to adjacent crops, and increased canola seed-set via native bee visitation, with some findings of fewer ground-nesting bees, and older hedgerows and native plants supporting more bee species [1407]; leaving arable field margins uncropped with natural regeneration, which in several replicated UK trials supported more foraging bumblebees and sometimes more bee species than cropped margins, though effects varied by year and plant composition, and some trials found similar richness to sown wildflowers or no increase over cropped margins [20]; sowing uncropped arable field margins with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes, which consistently attracted more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins, with legume-rich mixes often outperforming perennial wildflower mixes in year one, but with value declining over time without re-sowing [18]; establishing nectar flower mixture/wildflower strips, for which many studies reported increased invertebrate abundance and diversity, including support for ground beetles and evidence of greater activity or improved conditions, though some studies reported mixed or no effects [442]; and creating scrapes and pools, which increased aquatic macroinvertebrate diversity and provided habitat for scarce water beetles in constructed pools [153].

relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents on European farmland reports: Planting trees on farmland was associated with higher small mammal abundance than on arable land and similar abundance to uncultivated field margins and set-aside, and tree stands were used more by European hares than the wider farmed landscape (2386). Planting crops to provide supplementary food increased small mammal abundance in winter (UK) and increased European rabbit abundance (Spain) (2394). Reducing livestock grazing intensity was associated with increases in abundances of small mammals in several European studies, but did not increase European or Irish hare numbers (2408). Fencing to exclude predators or other problematic species increased abundances of small mammals in some studies and increased rabbit abundance when both terrestrial carnivores and raptors were excluded in Spain (2497). Prescribed burning showed mixed effects on small mammals, with some studies reporting increases in European rabbits and others finding no increase (2388). No studies were found evaluating maintaining/restoring/creating habitat connectivity for mammals on farmland (2381).

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of reducing or excluding livestock grazing on semi-natural farmland habitats?
relevant_summary: Across semi-natural habitats, reducing or excluding livestock grazing showed mixed outcomes: Benefits reported include increases in plant abundance/diversity and invertebrate diversity/abundance under reduced grazing intensity or seasonal removal, along with greater usage by geese and higher numbers of northern lapwing and common redshank, and benefits to breeding Eurasian skylark; removal of autumn grazing after a silage cut increased winter abundance of seed-eating birds [704]. Excluding livestock benefited plants and invertebrates in some studies [150], and, for mammals, increased small mammal species richness in two studies and higher abundances for some small mammals, mule deer, and (with water provision) European rabbits in several studies [2407]. In marshes, ungrazed areas had higher northern lapwing nest survival and clutch size than grazed areas [697]. Documented negative or neutral impacts include studies finding no benefits to plants, birds, or invertebrates when grazing was reduced or excluded [150, 704], mixed or neutral effects when exclusion was used as a restoration tool [150], and cases where grazing exclusion did not increase abundances of black-tailed hares, California ground squirrel burrows, or several small mammal species [2407]. On fenland, excluding cattle reduced the number of plant species, while reviews indicate low–medium grazing can have positive effects on fen biodiversity, sometimes needing additional management [697]. A systematic review concluded that intermediate grazing levels are usually optimal for plants, invertebrates and birds, with likely trade-offs between taxa [704].

query: What are the effects of different mowing management strategies—such as timing, height, and technique—on farmland wildlife?

Technique: Across Germany, Ireland, Switzerland and the UK, specific wildlife‑friendly mowing techniques reduced mortality or injury in birds, mammals, amphibians and invertebrates, and UK corncrake populations increased during periods when Corncrake Friendly Mowing schemes were introduced [698]; UK evidence also reports lower mortality of corncrakes and Eurasian skylarks with wildlife‑friendly mowing, alongside population increases following schemes that delayed mowing and promoted corncrake‑friendly techniques [192]. Mowing from the centre outwards allowed 68% of corncrake chicks to escape vs 45% with conventional edge‑in mowing [698]. Machinery choice affected outcomes: bar mowers and double‑chop mowers caused less damage or lower mortality for amphibians/invertebrates than alternatives, rotary disc mowers with conditioners killed about twice as many small mammals as double‑blade mowers, using a conditioner increased invertebrate injury/mortality in some studies, mower‑conditioners yielded higher Eurasian skylark nest survival than using a tedder, wider mowing machinery was associated with fourfold higher skylark chick survival, and swather mowers/forage harvesters had the highest skylark nest survival [698].

Twenty-six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of planting grass margins around arable or pasture fields. Seventeen were in the UK, two were in each of Sweden, the Netherlands and the USA, and one was in each of China, France and Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (15 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (15 studies): One of two replicated, controlled studies in the UK found that 2-m grass margins had a greater species richness of butterflies than cropped field edges, but 6-m grass margins did not. The other study found that the species richness of butterflies was similar in grass margins and cropped field edges. Five replicated, site comparison studies (including one paired study) in the USA, the UK and Italy found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a greater species richness or diversity of butterflies, macro-moths and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins, although one of these studies found that the species richness of macro-moths was similar in wide and conventional grass margins. Three of five replicated studies (including three randomized, controlled studies, one controlled study, and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a greater species richness of butterflies than standard grass margins. The other two studies found that farms with floristically enhanced margins (along with other enhanced agri-environment scheme (AES) options) had a similar species richness of butterflies and moths to farms with standard grass margins (along with basic AES options) and farms with no grass margins or other AES options. One site comparison study in Sweden found that grass margins sown with legumes or a clover and grass ley had a higher species richness of butterflies and moths than uncultivated margins, but less than a species-rich pasture. One replicated study in the Netherlands found that the species richness of butterflies increased over time after the establishment of grass margins. One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that disking or burning grass margins did not affect the species richness of butterflies.

POPULATION RESPONSE (22 STUDIES)

Abundance (21 studies): Three of four replicated, controlled studies in the UK found that grass margins had a higher abundance of butterflies than cropped field edges. The other study found that the abundance of gatekeepers on grass margins increased over four years after they were sown, but was only higher than cropped field edges at one of three farms after 2–4 years. Three of seven replicated, site comparison studies (including two paired studies) in the USA and the UK found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a higher abundance of habitat-sensitive butterflies, macro-moths and micro-moths than narrower or conventional width margins. Two of these studies, and the other four studies, found that the abundance of disturbance-tolerant butterflies, macro-moths generally, and pale shining brown moths specifically, was similar in wide and conventional grass margins. Four replicated studies (including two randomized, controlled studies, one controlled study, and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips had a higher abundance of butterflies than standard grass margins, uncultivated margins or margins sown with cereal crop. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the UK found that farms with floristically enhanced margins (along with other enhanced agri-environment scheme (AES) options) had a higher abundance of some butterflies and micro-moths, a similar abundance of macro-moths, but a lower abundance of other butterflies, than farms with standard grass margins (along with basic AES options) and farms with no grass margins or other AES options. Use (2 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in China found that grass margins around lightly cultivated fields were more likely to be occupied by marsh fritillary eggs and caterpillars than uncultivated, grazed meadows. One replicated, paired, site comparison study in France found that meadow brown butterflies used grass margins in a similar way to meadows."

Richness/diversity (20 studies): Eight of thirteen studies (including twelve replicated studies, two randomized studies, five controlled studies, one before-and-after study, and eight site comparison studies) in the UK, Switzerland, Finland and Germany found that sown wildflower strips had a higher species richness and diversity of all butterflies, generalist butterflies, and moths than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields or conventional grassland. One of these studies also found that the species richness of specialist butterflies was similar in sown wildflower strips, cropped fields and conventional grassland. Four studies found that the species richness of butterflies was similar between sown wildflower strips and cropped fields, cropped margins, unsown strips or extensively managed meadows. The other study found that, five years after sowing wildflower strips, butterfly species richness, but not diversity had increased at one of two study sites. One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that the species richness of butterflies and moths was similar on farms managed under agri-environment schemes, including with sown wildflower strips, and on conventionally managed farms. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that field margins sown with wildflowers had a greater species richness of butterflies than grass-only field margins. One of two replicated, paired, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in the USA and the UK found that plots sown with a mix of wildflowers had a greater species richness of caterpillars than plots sown with a single flower species. The other study found that plots sown with either complex or simpler flower mixes had a similar species richness of butterflies. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in the UK found that wildflower plots sown with phacelia, borage or lucerne had a higher species richness or diversity of butterflies and moths than plots sown with other flower species.

Abundance (17 studies): Ten studies (including nine replicated studies, three randomized studies, three controlled studies and seven site comparison studies) in the UK, Switzerland and Finland found that sown wildflower strips had a higher abundance of all butterflies, generalist butterflies, specialist butterflies and meadow brown butterflies than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields, cropped margins, conventional grassland or extensively managed meadows. However, one of these studies only found this effect in one of two study years. Two of these studies also found that the abundance of specialist butterflies and meadow brown caterpillars was similar in sown wildflower strips and unsown margins, cropped fields and conventional grassland, and one found that the abundance of caterpillars was lower in sown wildflower strips than in conventional grassland. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study and one site comparison study) in the UK and Sweden found that field margins sown with wildflowers had a higher abundance of butterflies than grass-only field margins. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that wildflower plots sown with lucerne had a higher abundance of butterflies than plots sown with borage, chicory or sainfoin.

Use (2 studies): Two studies (including one replicated study) in the UK and the USA reported that sown nectar flower plots and tropical milkweed plots were used by six species of butterflies and moths and monarch butterflies and caterpillars."

query: As an alternative to leaving overwinter stubbles in UK cereal fields, what other in-field management options are available to benefit seed-eating birds and other wildlife?
relevant_summary: Relevant in-field options include: creating skylark plots, which were associated with higher skylark densities and productivity in several UK studies, though one study found seed-eating songbirds did not use skylark plots more than surrounding crops (214); leaving cultivated, uncropped margins or plots (including lapwing plots), which provided benefits to a range of wildlife groups including some farmland birds, plants and invertebrates, though some studies reported mixed or no effects for certain bird species (562); sowing wild bird seed or cover mixtures, which multiple UK studies found increased bird abundance, density and diversity and benefited some invertebrates and plants, with some mixed/negative results also reported (594); planting cereals in wide-spaced rows, which showed mixed evidence for skylark benefits across UK studies (216); leaving unharvested cereal headlands within arable fields, for which no direct evidence on bird population effects was found (206); leaving headlands unsprayed (conservation headlands), which increased butterfly species richness and abundance compared to sprayed headlands in replicated, controlled studies (3898); planting grass buffer strips/margins, which in numerous studies increased abundance or richness of butterflies and moths, especially when wider or floristically enhanced (3982); creating beetle banks, which some reviews and studies linked with nesting/foraging by certain bird species and larger grey partridge populations where other measures were also used, though other studies found no strong associations (217); planting nectar flower mixture/wildflower strips, which some studies found were used by more birds than crops or other managements, with mixed winter use results (189); and sowing uncropped arable field margins with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes, which increased bumblebee foraging compared with naturally regenerated, grassy or cropped margins (18).

relevant_summary: Sown nectar flower mixtures/wildflower strips often had higher butterfly and moth species richness and diversity than conventional or unsown margins, cropped fields or conventional grassland, with several studies also reporting higher abundances; some studies found similar richness or mixed abundance responses, and strips were used by multiple butterfly and moth species (3932). Field margins sown with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes attracted significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy or cropped margins; mixes of agricultural forage plants (including legumes) attracted more bumblebees than perennial wildflower mixes in the first year, but margins with agricultural legumes degraded in value over time and required re-sowing every few years (18). Uncropped margins sown with native wild flower seed mixes supported higher abundance (and in several trials higher species richness) of foraging bumblebees than cropped edges, grassy margins or naturally regenerated margins; perennial leguminous herbs were important forage, and some long‑tongued bumblebees preferred perennial wildflower mixes over annual forage mixes (19). Planting nettle strips in arable margins increased the number of aphid predator species relative to crops, with some predator families only found on nettles, although nettle strips had fewer predators than crops and natural nettle patches had more predators than crops (118). For birds, some studies found more birds used nectar/wildflower strips than crops or other managements, while others found no winter increase; skylarks were more likely to nest, and less likely to abandon nests, in patches sown with annual weeds than in crops, and margin management influenced bird use more than seed mix (189).
